sankalps.truth_speech.tooltip: Truth, like Sarasvatī’s stream, purifies speech when kind and necessary.
sankalps.truth_speech.suggested: Before speaking, pause and ask: Is it true, kind, and needed?
sankalps.truth_speech.source: Yoga Sutra 2.30, principles of ethical living; Gita 17.15, guide to pure speech
sankalps.no_gossip.tooltip: Silence blooms where divisive words wither, honoring Mauna’s grace.
sankalps.no_gossip.suggested: If gossip begins, shift the topic or pause silently for 10 seconds.
sankalps.no_gossip.source: Bhagavad Gītā 17.15, a teaching on harmonious speech
sankalps.pause_before_react.tooltip: A breath, like Viṣṇu’s calm, grants freedom between trigger and response.
sankalps.pause_before_react.suggested: Take three breaths, invoking Kṣamā, before a heated reply.
sankalps.pause_before_react.source: Bhagavad Gītā 16.3, virtues of patience; Yoga Sutra 2.33, cultivating opposite thoughts
sankalps.listen_more.short: I will listen more than I speak.
sankalps.listen_more.tooltip: Listening, like Śiva’s silence, is sevā to the heart’s truth.
sankalps.listen_more.suggested: After they speak, wait five seconds, hearing their heart fully.
sankalps.listen_more.source: Vedānta, the practice of attentive listening and reflection
sankalps.speak_kindly.short: I will speak kindly to everyone.
sankalps.speak_kindly.tooltip: Words, like Lakṣmī’s grace, soothe when spoken with love.
sankalps.speak_kindly.suggested: Replace one criticism with a sincere compliment today.
sankalps.speak_kindly.source: Bhagavad Gītā 17.15, a guide to gentle and uplifting speech
sankalps.think_before_speak.short: I will think before I speak.
sankalps.think_before_speak.tooltip: A mindful pause, like Budha’s clarity, makes speech sacred.
sankalps.think_before_speak.source: Bhagavad Gītā 17.15, teachings on pure and thoughtful speech
sankalps.no_complaints.tooltip: Santoṣa, like a lotus, blooms where complaints fade.
sankalps.no_complaints.suggested: Catch one complaint; replace it with one gratitude aloud.
sankalps.no_complaints.source: Yoga Sutra 2.42, a teaching on the joy of contentment
sankalps.words_that_heal.short: I will choose words that heal, not hurt.
sankalps.words_that_heal.tooltip: Speak as if each word is a prayer to Kṛṣṇa’s flute.
sankalps.words_that_heal.suggested: Send one healing message to someone today.
sankalps.words_that_heal.source: Bhagavad Gītā 17.15, a guide to non-harming speech
sankalps.no_anger.short: I will not get angry today.
sankalps.no_anger.tooltip: Akrodha, like Hanumān’s courage, calms the heart’s fire.
sankalps.no_anger.suggested: When anger rises, sip water, chant ‘Śānti,’ and pause for 60 seconds.
sankalps.no_anger.source: Bhagavad Gītā 2.62–63, on mastering anger; 16.1–3, divine qualities
sankalps.choose_patience.short: I will choose patience over irritation.
sankalps.choose_patience.tooltip: Kṣamā, like Śiva’s stillness, holds strength gently.
sankalps.choose_patience.suggested: When delayed, breathe box-style: 4-4-4-4 for four cycles.
sankalps.choose_patience.source: Bhagavad Gītā 16.3, patience as virtue; 10.4–5, divine attributes
sankalps.forgive_one.short: I will forgive one person today.
sankalps.forgive_one.tooltip: Forgiveness, like Viṣṇu’s grace, frees the heart first.
sankalps.forgive_one.suggested: Whisper silently: ‘I release you; I choose peace.’
sankalps.forgive_one.source: Bhagavad Gītā 12.13–14, qualities of devotion; 16.3, forgiveness
sankalps.not_personal.short: I will not take things personally.
sankalps.not_personal.tooltip: Be the witness, like Sākṣī Śiva, not the wound.
sankalps.not_personal.suggested: Repeat: ‘This is their state, not my Self’s truth.’
sankalps.not_personal.source: Bhagavad Gītā 2.14, equanimity; 2.38, balance in action
sankalps.accept_change.short: I will accept what I cannot change.
sankalps.accept_change.tooltip: Waves pass, yet the ocean of Brahman remains.
sankalps.accept_change.suggested: Label it ‘uncontrollable’; act only on your dharma.
sankalps.smile_in_difficulty.short: I will smile even in difficulty.
sankalps.smile_in_difficulty.tooltip: A gentle smile, like Kṛṣṇa’s līlā, steadies the heart.
sankalps.smile_in_difficulty.suggested: Soften face, relax jaw, half-smile for 30 seconds.
sankalps.smile_in_difficulty.source: Bhagavad Gītā 2.56–57, qualities of a steady mind
sankalps.reduce_fear.tooltip: Courage, like Hanumān’s leap, walks through fear’s shadow.
sankalps.reduce_fear.suggested: Take one small step toward what you fear today.
sankalps.reduce_fear.source: Bhagavad Gītā 16.1, fearlessness as a divine quality
sankalps.no_envy.short: I will not compare or envy today.
sankalps.no_envy.tooltip: Your path, like Sūrya’s light, shines uniquely sacred.
sankalps.no_envy.suggested: Bless one person you compare yourself to silently.
sankalps.effort_over_result.short: I will put my best effort without worrying about results.
sankalps.effort_over_result.tooltip: Do your dharma, like Arjuna’s bow, and release the fruits.
sankalps.effort_over_result.suggested: Define one right action; let go of its outcome.
sankalps.effort_over_result.source: Bhagavad Gītā 2.47, a guide to selfless action
sankalps.see_divine_in_all.short: I will see the Divine in everyone I meet.
sankalps.see_divine_in_all.tooltip: See Viṣṇu in all; every heart holds the same Ātman.
sankalps.see_divine_in_all.suggested: Silently greet: ‘Namaste—the Divine in me honors you.’
sankalps.see_divine_in_all.source: Īśā Upaniṣad 1, all is divine; Gita 6.29, unity of Self
sankalps.solution_focus.short: I will focus on solutions, not problems.
sankalps.solution_focus.tooltip: Skillful action, like Kṛṣṇa’s counsel, grows where focus flows.
sankalps.solution_focus.suggested: For one problem, write two actionable steps today.
sankalps.solution_focus.source: Bhagavad Gītā 2.50, a teaching on skillful action
sankalps.stay_calm.short: I will stay calm in all situations.
sankalps.stay_calm.tooltip: Samatvam, like Śiva’s stillness, is yoga’s heart.
sankalps.stay_calm.suggested: Anchor breath to mantra: ‘So’ on inhale, ‘Ham’ on exhale, for one minute.
sankalps.stay_calm.source: Bhagavad Gītā 2.48, equanimity in action; 2.56, steady wisdom
sankalps.challenge_opportunity.short: I will treat challenges as opportunities.
sankalps.challenge_opportunity.tooltip: Tapas, like Skanda’s spear, forges growth in adversity’s fire.
sankalps.challenge_opportunity.suggested: Reframe one setback: write its lesson in one line.
sankalps.let_go_be_right.short: I will let go of the need to be right.
sankalps.let_go_be_right.tooltip: Ego’s surrender, like a feather in Śiva’s dance, brings harmony.
sankalps.let_go_be_right.suggested: In one debate, say: ‘You may be right—let me reflect.’
sankalps.begin_again.short: If I slip, I will begin again without guilt.
sankalps.begin_again.tooltip: Abhyāsa, like a river’s flow, restarts with gentle resolve.
sankalps.begin_again.suggested: Notice a slip, smile, and restart—no self-blame.
sankalps.learn_daily.short: I will learn one new thing today.
sankalps.learn_daily.tooltip: Svādhyāya, like Bṛhaspati’s light, keeps the mind ever young.
sankalps.learn_daily.suggested: Read one śloka or line; note one takeaway in your heart.
sankalps.learn_daily.source: Yoga Sutra 2.44, a practice of self-study
sankalps.help_one_person.short: I will help at least one person today.
sankalps.help_one_person.tooltip: Sevā, like Hanumān’s strength, serves the Divine in all.
sankalps.help_one_person.suggested: Offer one concrete help: a task, ride, meal, or kind word.
sankalps.help_one_person.source: Bhagavad Gītā 3.19–20, selfless service as yoga
sankalps.smile_at_all.short: I will smile at everyone I meet.
sankalps.smile_at_all.tooltip: Your smile, like Kṛṣṇa’s joy, is prasāda for the world.
sankalps.smile_at_all.suggested: Meet three people today with a heartfelt smile.
sankalps.feed_being.short: I will feed a being today (person, bird, animal).
sankalps.feed_being.tooltip: Feeding another, like Annapūrṇā’s grace, nourishes your soul.
sankalps.feed_being.suggested: Offer fruit or grain before sunset, chanting ‘Dayā’ softly.
sankalps.check_on_someone.short: I will check on someone who needs support.
sankalps.check_on_someone.tooltip: Karunā, like Lakṣmī’s touch, heals through a caring call.
sankalps.check_on_someone.suggested: Call or message one person who’s been quiet lately.
sankalps.share_knowledge.short: I will share knowledge without expectation.
sankalps.share_knowledge.tooltip: Jñāna-dāna, like Bṛhaspati’s wisdom, is worship freely given.
sankalps.share_knowledge.suggested: Offer one helpful tip or resource to someone today.
sankalps.share_knowledge.source: Bhagavad Gītā 18.5–6, selfless giving; 17.20–22, pure charity
sankalps.secret_kindness.short: I will do one act of kindness in secret.
sankalps.secret_kindness.tooltip: Hidden kindness, like a lamp in Śiva’s shrine, lights the soul.
sankalps.secret_kindness.source: Bhagavad Gītā 17.20, pure and selfless giving
sankalps.speak_uplift.short: I will speak to uplift someone’s day.
sankalps.speak_uplift.tooltip: Words of uplift, like Kṛṣṇa’s flute, brighten the heart’s sky.
sankalps.speak_uplift.suggested: Send a two-line appreciation to one person today.
sankalps.be_present.short: I will listen fully when someone speaks.
sankalps.be_present.tooltip: Presence, like Viṣṇu’s gaze, is the purest gift of love.
sankalps.be_present.suggested: In one chat, no interruptions, no phone, full eye contact.
sankalps.be_present.source: Yoga Sutra 1.33, cultivating faith and friendliness
sankalps.thank_three.short: I will thank the Divine for three things today.
sankalps.thank_three.tooltip: Gratitude, like Lakṣmī’s lotus, turns enough into abundance.
sankalps.thank_three.suggested: List three blessings aloud after lunch, offering thanks as prasāda.
sankalps.thank_three.source: Bhagavad Gītā 2.57, acceptance; 3.11–13, gratitude as offering
sankalps.be_content.short: I will be content with what I have.
sankalps.be_content.tooltip: Santoṣa, like a heart’s lotus, blooms in what is.
sankalps.be_content.suggested: Repeat softly: ‘I have enough. I am enough.’
sankalps.be_content.source: Yoga Sutra 2.42, a teaching on the joy of contentment
sankalps.notice_blessings.short: I will notice blessings, not shortcomings.
sankalps.notice_blessings.tooltip: Sattva-dṛṣṭi, like Sūrya’s rays, finds grace in all.
sankalps.notice_blessings.suggested: Catch one complaint; replace with one blessing noticed.
sankalps.notice_blessings.source: Bhagavad Gītā 2.55–57, cultivating a pure vision
sankalps.appreciate_small.short: I will appreciate one small thing I overlook.
sankalps.appreciate_small.tooltip: Ārjava, like a breeze, reveals the sacred in the ordinary.
sankalps.appreciate_small.suggested: Name aloud one small joy: a breeze, tea, or smile.
sankalps.appreciate_small.source: Bhagavad Gītā 16.1–3, simplicity; Yoga Sutra 2.42, contentment
sankalps.write_gratitude.short: I will write down three things I’m grateful for.
sankalps.write_gratitude.tooltip: Smaraṇa, like a pen’s prayer, imprints gratitude on the heart.
sankalps.write_gratitude.suggested: Jot three lines before sleep; keep a notepad by bed.
sankalps.write_gratitude.source: Yoga Sutra 2.44, a practice of self-study and remembrance
sankalps.thank_someone.short: I will thank someone directly today.
sankalps.thank_someone.tooltip: Gratitude spoken, like Lakṣmī’s gift, completes the heart’s circle.
sankalps.thank_someone.suggested: Send a 20-word thank-you to one person today.
sankalps.thank_someone.source: Yoga Sutra 1.33, cultivating friendliness and gratitude
sankalps.no_wanting.short: I will not chase what I don’t need today.
sankalps.no_wanting.tooltip: Aparigraha, like Śani’s discipline, frees the soul from desire’s chains.
sankalps.no_wanting.suggested: Skip one impulse buy; note the freedom in your heart.
sankalps.no_wanting.source: Yoga Sutra 2.39, a teaching on non-possession
sankalps.accept_self.short: I will accept myself as I am today.
sankalps.accept_self.tooltip: Ātma-sammāna, like Viṣṇu’s embrace, is sattva for the soul.
sankalps.accept_self.suggested: Look in the mirror; say one kind sentence to yourself.
sankalps.accept_self.source: Bhagavad Gītā 6.5–6, uplifting the self; Yoga Sutra 2.42, contentment
sankalps.avoid_junk.short: I will avoid junk food today.
sankalps.avoid_junk.tooltip: Mitāhāra, like a sattvic flame, fuels a clear mind.
sankalps.avoid_junk.suggested: Swap one processed snack for fruit or nuts today.
sankalps.avoid_junk.source: Hatha Yoga Pradipika 1.58, a teaching on balanced diet
sankalps.wake_early.short: I will wake up before sunrise.
sankalps.wake_early.tooltip: Brahma-muhūrta, like Sūrya’s dawn, primes the heart’s clarity.
sankalps.wake_early.suggested: Rise in Brahma-muhūrta, offering one chant to the Divine.
sankalps.wake_early.source: Aṣṭāṅga Hṛdayam Su.2, a teaching on sacred morning time
sankalps.ten_min_silence.short: I will spend ten minutes in silence.
sankalps.ten_min_silence.tooltip: Mauna, like Śiva’s stillness, resets the soul’s scattered light.
sankalps.ten_min_silence.suggested: Set a 10-minute timer; sit straight, no phone, in silence.
sankalps.ten_min_silence.source: Dharmic tradition, a practice of sacred silence
sankalps.no_phone_first_hour.short: I will avoid my phone for the first hour.
sankalps.no_phone_first_hour.tooltip: Guard your dawn, like Śiva’s calm, to honor the mind’s purity.
sankalps.no_phone_first_hour.suggested: Keep phone outside bedroom; chant a śloka instead.
sankalps.good_posture.short: I will maintain good posture today.
sankalps.good_posture.tooltip: Sthira-sukha, like a yogi’s āsana, aligns prāṇa and mind.
sankalps.good_posture.suggested: Set two posture reminders; lengthen spine each time.
sankalps.good_posture.source: Yoga Sutra 2.46, a teaching on steady and comfortable posture
sankalps.finish_what_start.short: I will finish what I start.
sankalps.finish_what_start.tooltip: Dhṛti, like Śani’s resolve, builds power through completion.
sankalps.finish_what_start.suggested: Pick one half-done task; complete it before noon.
sankalps.finish_what_start.source: Bhagavad Gītā 18.33, steadfastness; 17.3, faith in action
sankalps.no_sugar.short: I will avoid added sugar today.
sankalps.no_sugar.tooltip: Mitāhāra, like a sattvic stream, brings stillness to the body.
sankalps.no_sugar.suggested: Choose unsweetened tea or coffee once today.
sankalps.no_sugar.source: Hatha Yoga Pradipika 1.58, a teaching on pure nourishment
sankalps.no_unnecessary_spend.short: I will not spend on non-essentials today.
sankalps.no_unnecessary_spend.tooltip: Aparigraha, like Śani’s discipline, frees you from want’s weight.
sankalps.no_unnecessary_spend.suggested: Delay one purchase by 24 hours; feel the lightness.
sankalps.no_unnecessary_spend.source: Yoga Sutra 2.39, a teaching on non-possession
sankalps.remember_name_meals.short: I will remember God’s name before each meal.
sankalps.remember_name_meals.tooltip: Prasāda-buddhi, like Annapūrṇā’s offering, sanctifies every bite.
sankalps.remember_name_meals.suggested: Chant ‘Oṁ’ once silently before the first bite.
sankalps.remember_name_meals.source: Bhagavad Gītā 4.24, food as offering; 3.13, sanctified eating
sankalps.mantra_11.short: I will chant a mantra 11 times today.
sankalps.mantra_11.tooltip: Japa, like a garland for Kṛṣṇa, weaves grace bead by bead.
sankalps.mantra_11.suggested: Pick one name (Rāma, Kṛṣṇa, Śiva) and chant 11 times.
sankalps.mantra_11.source: Bhāgavata Purāṇa 12.3.51, a practice of devotional chanting
sankalps.read_one_verse.short: I will read one verse from a scripture.
sankalps.read_one_verse.tooltip: Svādhyāya, like Bṛhaspati’s lamp, lights the mind’s path.
sankalps.read_one_verse.suggested: Read one Gītā śloka; note one line that stirs your heart.
sankalps.read_one_verse.source: Yoga Sutra 2.44, a practice of scriptural study
sankalps.inner_bow.short: I will bow inwardly before beginning work.
sankalps.inner_bow.tooltip: Offer work to Īśvara, like a flower at Śiva’s feet.
sankalps.inner_bow.suggested: Close eyes for five seconds; say inwardly, ‘For You.’
sankalps.inner_bow.source: Yoga Sutra 2.45, surrender to the Divine
sankalps.five_min_prayer.short: I will spend five minutes in prayer.
sankalps.five_min_prayer.tooltip: Prayer, like Kṛṣṇa’s call, is the heart’s song to the Divine.
sankalps.five_min_prayer.suggested: Set a five-minute timer; speak to your Iṣṭa with simple honesty.
sankalps.five_min_prayer.source: Nārada Bhakti Sūtra, a tradition of devotional love
sankalps.work_as_offering.short: I will see my work as an offering.
sankalps.work_as_offering.tooltip: Karma-Yoga, like a yajña, makes every task a temple.
sankalps.work_as_offering.suggested: Begin one task with: ‘This is my offering today.’
sankalps.work_as_offering.source: Bhagavad Gītā 3.9, work as sacred offering
sankalps.om_three_times.short: I will chant Om three times before tasks.
sankalps.om_three_times.tooltip: Oṁ, like Śiva’s drum, tunes the mind to the One.
sankalps.om_three_times.suggested: Chant Oṁ three times softly before one key task.
sankalps.om_three_times.source: Māṇḍūkya Upaniṣad 1–2, a teaching on the sacred syllable
sankalps.remember_guru.short: I will remember my Guru’s guidance today.
sankalps.remember_guru.tooltip: Guru-smaraṇa, like a lamp, guides the heart’s steps.
sankalps.remember_guru.suggested: Recall one Guru’s teaching; live it in one action today.
sankalps.remember_guru.source: Guru Gītā, a hymn to the eternal teacher
sankalps.no_waste_water.short: I will not waste water today.
sankalps.no_waste_water.tooltip: Water, like Gaṅgā’s gift, is sacred; use it with reverence.
sankalps.no_waste_water.suggested: Close tap while soaping; save one bucket today.
sankalps.no_waste_water.source: Gaṅgā-stotra, a hymn to the sacred river
sankalps.feed_bird_animal.short: I will feed a bird or animal today.
sankalps.feed_bird_animal.tooltip: Dayā, like Annapūrṇā’s grace, feeds all beings as one.
sankalps.feed_bird_animal.suggested: Offer grains or water outside in morning or evening.
sankalps.feed_bird_animal.source: Bhagavad Gītā 12.4, unity; 12.13, compassion for all
sankalps.care_for_plant.short: I will water or care for a plant.
sankalps.care_for_plant.tooltip: Vṛkṣa-sevā, like Lakṣmī’s touch, nurtures prāṇa’s green.
sankalps.care_for_plant.suggested: Water one plant, chanting ‘Oṁ Namaḥ Śivāya’ softly.
sankalps.care_for_plant.source: Dharmic tradition, reverence for nature’s life
sankalps.no_plastic_bag.short: I will avoid plastic bags today.
sankalps.no_plastic_bag.tooltip: Ahimsā, like Pṛthvī’s care, chooses reusable over waste.
sankalps.no_plastic_bag.suggested: Carry a cloth bag in your vehicle or backpack.
sankalps.keep_surroundings_clean.short: I will keep my surroundings clean.
sankalps.keep_surroundings_clean.tooltip: Śauca, like a temple’s purity, clears space and mind.
sankalps.keep_surroundings_clean.suggest: Declutter one surface (desk or shelf) for three minutes.
sankalps.keep_surroundings_clean.source: Yoga Sutra 2.32, a teaching on inner and outer purity
sankalps.walk_short_trips.short: I will walk short trips instead of driving.
sankalps.walk_short_trips.tooltip: Tapas, like Sūrya’s stride, treads lightly on Pṛthvī.
sankalps.walk_short_trips.suggested: For one errand under 1 km, walk with mindful steps.
sankalps.mindful_energy.short: I will switch off lights and save energy.
sankalps.mindful_energy.tooltip: Ṛta, like Sūrya’s order, aligns with mindful stewardship.
sankalps.mindful_energy.suggested: Turn off two idle lights or devices today.
sankalps.mindful_energy.source: Vedic ethos, harmony with cosmic order
sankalps.respect_food.short: I will not waste food today.
sankalps.respect_food.tooltip: Anna-devatā, like Annapūrṇā’s grace, is sacred in every grain.
sankalps.respect_food.suggested: Serve smaller portions; finish before taking more.
